title: T. Natarajan
text:
Thangarasu Natarajan (born 4 April 1991) is an Indian <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er. He made his international debut for the <a href="India%20national%20cricket%20team">India cricket team</a> in December 2020. He plays for <a href="Sunrisers%20Hyderabad">Sunrisers Hyderabad</a> in the <a href="Indian%20Premier%20League">Indian Premier League</a> (IPL) and for <a href="Tamil%20Nadu%20cricket%20team">Tamil Nadu</a> in domestic cricket. He became the first Indian cricketer to make his international debut across all three formats on the same tour when he was playing in <a href="Indian%20cricket%20team%20in%20Australia%20in%202020%E2%80%9321">India's 2020–21 tour of Australia</a>.
Early life.
Natarajan was born in Chinnappampatti, a village near <a href="Salem%2C%20Tamil%20Nadu">Salem</a> in <a href="Tamil%20Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a>. His father S. Thangarasu, was a <a href="Weaving">weaver</a> working on a powerloom, and his mother runs a fast-food stall. Natarajan is the eldest of five children. In November 2020, his wife gave birth to a baby girl.
Career.
Natarajan made his <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class</a> debut for <a href="Tamil%20Nadu%20cricket%20team">Tamil Nadu</a> in the <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20Ranji%20Trophy">2014–15 Ranji Trophy</a> on 5 January 2015. He made his <a href="Twenty20">Twenty20</a> debut for Tamil Nadu in the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Inter%20State%20Twenty-20%20Tournament">2016–17 Inter State Twenty-20 Tournament</a> on 29 January 2017. He made his <a href="List%20A%20cricket">List A</a> debut for Tamil Nadu in the <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20Vijay%20Hazare%20Trophy">2018–19 Vijay Hazare Trophy</a> on 20 September 2018.
In February 2017, Natarajan was bought by the <a href="Kings%20XI%20Punjab">Kings XI Punjab</a> team for the <a href="2017%20Indian%20Premier%20League">2017 Indian Premier League</a> for . In January 2018, he was bought by the <a href="Sunrisers%20Hyderabad">Sunrisers Hyderabad</a> in the <a href="List%20of%202018%20Indian%20Premier%20League%20personnel%20changes">2018 IPL auction</a>.
On 26 October 2020, Natarajan was named as one of four additional bowlers to travel with the <a href="India%20national%20cricket%20team">India cricket team</a> for their <a href="Indian%20cricket%20team%20in%20Australia%20in%202020%E2%80%9321">tour to Australia</a>. On 9 November 2020, he was added to India's <a href="Twenty20%20International">Twenty20 International</a> (T20I) squad, replacing <a href="Varun%20Chakravarthy">Varun Chakravarthy</a> who was ruled out due to an injury. Ahead of the first <a href="One%20Day%20International">One Day International</a> (ODI) match, he was added to India's squad as a cover for <a href="Navdeep%20Saini">Navdeep Saini</a>, who was suffering with a back spasm. Natarajan made his ODI debut for India against <a href="Australia%20national%20cricket%20team">Australia</a> on 2 December 2020. He made his T20I debut for India, also against Australia, on 4 December 2020, taking three wickets for thirty runs. On 30 December 2020, Natarajan was added to India's <a href="Test%20cricket">Test</a> squad ahead of the third match against Australia. He made his Test debut against Australia on 15 January 2021, dismissing <a href="Matthew%20Wade">Matthew Wade</a> for his first international Test wicket.
